conversations.content: Nameless-Mountain Master: Part One
Long ago, a lizard, an eagle, and a bat lived on a nameless mountain, where the three beasts quarreled without end over who was the greatest among them.
A dragon lived on the mountain as well, but the three beasts never bothered with her, for she was just a small child.
Secretly, however, the young dragon thought she was the greatest on the mountain, and she resolved to make the others see that.
One day, rumor reached them that an official from the Kingdom of Alberia was coming to see who ruled over the mountain.
This was the beasts' chance to prove to the world who was the master of the mountain once and for all. But how would they do it?
＂What if you each sculpt a big statue?＂ the young dragon said to the three beasts. ＂That way, even humans can tell at a glance who the master of this mountain is.＂
Each of the beasts felt this to be a fine idea, and ordered the animals under their charge to make a statue in their likeness.
The beasts adored the final products, and each boasted of their statue to  the others. ...But that was a mistake.
＂The others seem proud of their works,＂ grumbled the lizard. ＂If all three of us have equally fine statues, how is the human to know which of us truly rules the mountain?＂
The lizard snuck out in the middle of the night and destroyed the eagle's statue. But others had the same idea, for the eagle ruined the bat's statue, and the bat smashed the lizard's.
It was horrible. The statues of all three beasts were destroyed, and the kingdom official was due to arrive the very next day...
Nameless-Mountain Master: Part Two
The three beasts awoke that morning to find their beloved statues ruined beyond all hope of repair.
They had no time to make their statues anew, and bemoaned how they had quarreled in the first place. It was at this point that the young dragon came upon them.
＂I have an idea,＂ she said with a grin. ＂Take the parts of your statues that are still intact and combine them into a single figure—then all will know this mountain has THREE masters.＂
The three beasts heartily approved of this plan, and spent all night creating the new statue.
The next day, the official arrived. When he saw the statue, he said, ＂The scales of a lizard, the wings of a bat, and the claws of an eagle? Surely this must be a dragon!＂
＂So a great dragon rules over the beasts of this mountain, does it? Well, it would upset the balance of nature for a human to set foot upon this sacred land.＂
He marked the nameless mountain on his map with four words: HERE THERE BE DRAGONS. And while the beasts knew they had been tricked, they could do nothing about it.
Thus did the young dragon settle for good and all the question of who was the greatest on the mountain.
